abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings assess project outcomes as
            satisfactory, despite an unlikely sustainability, and modest
            institutional development impacts. Lessons show that
            adapting an effective, agricultural extension management
            system to the conditions of the country, substantially
            exceed the high costs involved in establishing and modifying
            extension management, as based on the increased
            productivity. Whereas support by adaptive and participative
            agricultural research is necessary, initially though, the
            best practices of existing traditional known technology, may
            well provide the adequate training material, tested on
            farmers' fields, further allowing substantial
            productivity, and income improvements. Although the cotton
            sector was not specifically included in the project, an
            important lesson drawn from the project suggests that
            specific measures could have been taken to support a sector
            as critical as cotton is in Chad, following the decline of
            cotton prices. Nongovernmental organizations (NGOs), and
            bilateral agencies can be effective implementation agencies
            for special types of components, though not necessarily less
            expensive than Government agencies. To this end, the high
            administrative, and operational costs absorbed by NGOs,
            require that measures be developed to reduce costs. The use
            of producer organizations as a basis for village
            investments, provide benefits beyond those strictly
            economic: provides a forum to fight HIV/AIDS; promotes the
            position of women; and, improves communal, environmental understanding.
